Because the state inspection programs are required to be ‚Äòat least equal to‚Äô or better than the federal inspection standards, products that pass state inspection should be able to be sold across state lines.
Currently in South Dakota, cattle, sheep, swine and goat products are limited to markets within the state even though they are required to go through inspection at an FSIS-approved state facility.

Today, @SenAngusKing and I introduced a bill to allow local meat & poultry products to be sold across state lines. At a time of economic downturn in the ag sector, opening up new markets for SD products is critically important.

But the whole point of the blue slip process is to protect the ability of the home-state Senators to look out for the interests of their constituents and ensure that the judicial nominees who are up for lifetime appointments in the courts of their states are qualified and vetted.
Under this Republican Congress, this convention is being violated because the majority wants to confirm judges that they agree with ideologically and as quickly as possible.

No Democratic Judiciary Committee Chairman has ever held a hearing for a nominee over the objections of a Republican home-state Senator.
Both Senators from the state where the judge is up for the appointment need to signal their approval for things to move forward. This process has been in place for 100 years.

Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs going on in the Senate Judiciary Committee right now: traditionally, judicial appointments are only considered once Senators from the state where the nominee will be appointed indicate their approval by turning in what we call a ‚Äúblue slip.‚Äù

#OneMoreVote

Third, the CRA will prevent ISPs from setting up internet fast and slow lanes. ISPs won‚Äôt be able to charge large websites for access to an internet fast lane while websites that can‚Äôt afford the internet EZ pass will load at a bumper to bumper pace.
Second, the CRA will ensure ISPs cannot throttle, or slow down, a website of their choosing, especially a competitor.

First, the CRA will protect websites from being entirely blocked by ISPs (internet service providers). That means an ISP cannot block a video chat service, just so you‚Äôll use their own service. And it will prevent ISPs from blocking a website with a contrary political viewpoint.

Next week‚Äôs vote on my resolution to *fully* restore #NetNeutrality will be the most important vote for the internet in the history of the United States Senate.
